title: 103_hr4999
content: The "Civil Rights Commission Amendments Act of 1994" amends the United States Commission on Civil Rights Act of 1983 by establishing the Commission and providing a short title for the Act. The United States Commission on Civil Rights, established by the Civil Rights Commission Amendments Act of 1994, consists of 8 members with a limit of 4 from the same political party. Members are appointed by the President and the President pro tempore of the Senate based on recommendations from leaders. The United States Commission on Civil Rights consists of 8 members with a limit of 4 from the same political party. Members are appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and Senate leaders. The term of office for each member is 6 years, with initial members' terms expiring on September 30, 1994. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson roles are initially filled by individuals serving on September 30, 1994. The President, with the majority of the Commission's members, can designate a Chairperson or Vice Chairperson. A vacancy can be filled in the same manner. The Vice Chairperson acts in the absence of the Chairperson. Members can only be removed for neglect of duty or malfeasance. A quorum consists of 5 members. The Commission's duties are outlined in Section 3. The Commission is mandated to investigate written allegations under oath regarding deprivations of voting rights based on color, race, religion, sex, age, disability, national origin, or fraud. It is also tasked with studying laws and policies of the Federal Government, serving as a national information clearinghouse, and creating public service announcements to combat discrimination and denials of equal protection under the law. The Commission is responsible for investigating allegations of voting rights deprivations based on various factors. It is also required to submit annual reports on civil rights enforcement efforts in the United States. The Commission is prohibited from investigating certain organizations' membership practices or internal operations. The Commission may establish advisory committees in each State and the District of Columbia composed of citizens. It has the power to hold hearings for carrying out its duties as outlined in the Act. The Commission has the power to hold hearings and establish advisory committees in each State and the District of Columbia. Members can administer oaths, issue subpoenas for witnesses, and approve hearings with a majority vote. Subpoenas cannot require witnesses to travel more than 100 miles from their location. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witnesses and obtain orders to enforce them in Federal court. Witnesses attending Commission proceedings are entitled to fees and mileage. Depositions and interrogatories can be used to gather information for hearings or reports. No authorization is given for the Commission or its committees to be involved in abortion-related matters. Depositions and interrogatories can be used to gather information for hearings or reports. No involvement in abortion-related matters is authorized. "SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS." The Commission shall have a full-time staff director appointed by the President with the concurrence of a majority of the Commission. It may appoint other personnel and procure services within its appropriations. Services can be obtained at rates not exceeding those for GS-15 positions. The Commission members receive compensation based on their status, with non-government members receiving a set amount and government members serving without additional pay but receiving travel expenses. The Commission members receive compensation based on their status, with non-government members receiving a set amount and government members serving without additional pay but receiving travel expenses. The Commission shall not accept voluntary or uncompensated personnel. The Commission may make rules necessary to carry out the purposes of the Act, with old rules continuing until modified by the Commission. In 1994, the initial rules of the Commission were established. All Federal agencies must fully cooperate with the Commission to ensure it can effectively carry out its functions and duties. Authorization of $9,500,000 for fiscal year 1995 to carry out the Act, with a prohibition on creating additional regional offices. The Act will terminate on September 30, 1995.
